dialogs.original: Last night, I hear, they lay at Stony Stratford,And at Northampton they do rest tonight.Tomorrow or next day they will be here.
dialogs.translated: I hear that last night they slept at Stony Stratford, and tonight they'll rest in Northampton. Tomorrow or the next day they'll be here.

dialogs.original: I long with all my heart to see the prince. I hope he is much grown since last I saw him.
dialogs.translated: I long with all my heart to see the prince. I hope he's grown a lot since the last time I saw him.

dialogs.original: But I hear no; they say my son of YorkHas almost overta'en him in his growth.
dialogs.translated: I heard he hasn't though. They say that my son of York has almost passed him in height.

dialogs.original: Ay, mother, but I would not have it so.
dialogs.translated: Yes, Mother, but I wish it weren't so.

dialogs.original: Why, my young cousin? It is good to grow.
dialogs.translated: Why, my child? It is good to grow.

dialogs.original: Grandam, one night as we did sit at supper,    My uncle Rivers talked how I did grow    More than my brother:   Ay, quoth my uncle Gloucester,    Small herbs have grace; great weeds do grow apace.    And since, methinks I would not grow so fast    Because sweet flowers are slow and weeds make haste.
dialogs.translated: Grandmother, one night while we were eating dinner, my uncle Rivers mentioned that I had grown more than my brother. "Yes," said my uncle Richard, "Small herbs grow with grace, while big weeds grow quickly." And since then, I've wished that I wouldn't grow so fast, because sweet flowers are slow, and weeds are hasty.

dialogs.original: Good faith, good faith, the saying did not hold    In him that did object the same to thee!    He was the wretchedst thing when he was young,    So long a-growing and so leisurely,    That if this rule were true, he should be gracious.
dialogs.translated: Honestly, honestly, that saying certainly didn't hold true for Richard! He was a terrible child, and took such a long time to grow up that if that rule were true, he should be a very gracious adult.

dialogs.original: And so no doubt he is, my gracious madam.
dialogs.translated: And no doubt he is, my gracious madam.

dialogs.original: I hope he is, but yet let mothers doubt.
dialogs.translated: I hope he is, but mothers can have their doubts.

dialogs.original: Now, by my troth, if I had been remembered,I could have given my uncles grace a flout To touch his growth nearer than he touched mine.
dialogs.translated: Now, if I'd considered something I once heard about him, I could have scoffed at my uncleand mocked his growth more than he mocked mine.

dialogs.original: How, my pretty York? I prithee let me hear it.
dialogs.translated: How, my clever York? Let me hear your comeback.

dialogs.original: Marry, they say my uncle grew so fast    That he could gnaw a crust at two hours old.    'Twas full two years ere I could get a tooth.    Grandam, this would have been a biting jest.
dialogs.translated: Well, they say that my uncle grew so fast that he could gnaw a crust of bread at two hours old. For me, it took two full years before I could get a single tooth. Grandmother, this would have been a biting joke.

dialogs.original: I prithee, pretty York, who told thee this?
dialogs.translated: Please tell me, clever York, who told you this about him?

dialogs.original: Grandam, his nurse.
dialogs.translated: His nurse, grandmother.

dialogs.original: His nurse? Why, she was dead ere thou wast born.
dialogs.translated: His nurse? Why, she was dead before you were born.

dialogs.original: If twere not she, I cannot tell who told me.
dialogs.translated: If it wasn't her, then I can't say who told me.

dialogs.original: A parlous boy! Go to, you are too shrewd.
dialogs.translated: A cunning boy! Get out of here, you're too clever for your own good.

dialogs.original: Good madam, be not angry with the child.
dialogs.translated: Good madam, don't be angry with the child.

dialogs.original: Pitchers have ears.
dialogs.translated: Little pitchers have wide ears.

dialogs.original: Here comes a messenger. What news?
dialogs.translated: Here comes a messenger.

dialogs.original: Such news, my lord, as grieves me to report.
dialogs.translated: It's news that grieves me to report, my lord.

dialogs.original: How doth the prince?
dialogs.translated: How is the prince?

dialogs.original: Well, madam, and in health.
dialogs.translated: Madam, he's well and in good health.

dialogs.original: What is thy news then?
dialogs.translated: What's your news then?

dialogs.original: Lord Rivers and Lord Grey are sent to Pomfret,And, with them, Sir Thomas Vaughan, prisoners.
dialogs.translated: Lord Rivers and Lord Grey have been sent to Pomfret, and Sir Thomas Vaughan with them. They're all prisoners.

dialogs.original: Who hath committed them?
dialogs.translated: Who had them arrested?

dialogs.original: The mighty dukes, Gloucester and Buckingham.
dialogs.translated: The mighty dukes of Gloucester and Buckingham.

dialogs.original: For what offence?
dialogs.translated: For what crime?

dialogs.original: The sum of all I can, I have disclosed.Why, or for what, the nobles were committedIs all unknown to me, my gracious lord.
dialogs.translated: I've told you all that I know. Why the nobles were arrested, and on what charges, is all unknown to me, my gracious lord.

dialogs.original: Ay me! I see the ruin of my house.    The tiger now hath seized the gentle hind.    Insulting tyranny begins to jut    Upon the innocent and aweless throne.    Welcome, destruction, blood, and massacre.    I see, as in a map, the end of all.
dialogs.translated: God help us! I see the ruin of my family. The tiger has now seized the gentle deer. Brute tyranny begins to attack the innocent, weak throne. Welcome, destruction, blood, and massacre! I can see how this will end as clearly as if I was reading it on a map.

dialogs.original: Accursèd and unquiet wrangling days,    How many of you have mine eyes beheld?    My husband lost his life to get the crown,    And often up and down my sons were tossed    For me to joy, and weep, their gain and loss.    And being seated, and domestic broils    Clean overblown, themselves the conquerors    Make war upon themselves, brother to brother,    Blood to blood, self against self.   O, preposterous    And frantic outrage, end thy damnèd spleen,    Or let me die, to look on death no more.
dialogs.translated: Oh, how many cursed and violent days of unrest have my old eyes seen? My husband lost his life to get the crown. And my sons' lives have been tossed up and down for me to rejoice over their gains and weep over their losses. And when one of them gained the throne and got rid of the domestic quarrels, now the conquerors turn on each other, making war among themselvesbrother against brother, blood against blood, self against self. Oh, it's a perversion of the natural order, a frenzied outrage! Let it endor let me dieso I won't have to see any more death.

dialogs.original: [to YORK]  Come, come, my boy. We will to sanctuary.Madam, farewell.
dialogs.translated: [To YORK] Come, come, my boy. We'll go take sanctuary. Madam, farewell.

dialogs.original: Stay, I will go with you.
dialogs.translated: Wait, I will go with you.

dialogs.original: You have no cause.
dialogs.translated: You have no reason to.

dialogs.original: [to QUEEN ELIZABETH]     My gracious lady, go,    And thither bear your treasure and your goods.    For my part, Ill resign unto your Grace    The seal I keep; and so betide to me    As well I tender you and all of yours.    Go. Ill conduct you to the sanctuary.
dialogs.translated: [To QUEEN ELIZABETH] My gracious lady, go. And take your money and belongings with you. For my part, I'll reassign the seal I keep to you, and I'll try to take care of you and all your relatives. Go, I'll conduct you to the sanctuary.
